title: Tire treads that grip in the dry and keep control in snow without killing processability
caption: CASE Tire treads that grip in the dry and keep control in snow without killing processability Overview On real roads, tires don‚Äôt get to pick the weather. One day it is hot, dry asphalt and the next one it‚Äôs snowy. In tires, the tread is the heart of vehicle control: what you decide here dictates how the car brakes and how it finds traction on both dry asphalt and snow. Historically, a tread that feels razor-sharp in the dry goes vague in snow, and a snow-biased recipe goes much on clean pavement. When the formulation leans too far to one side, the risk is immediate. The Challenge If you over-prioritize dry, the car ‚Äúfloats‚Äù on snow: long braking distances, loss of directional control, warranty pains and incidents. If you swing to the other extreme, the rubber becomes too ‚Äúsoft‚Äù for dry: steering turns spongy, compound temperature rises, and chipping and irregular wear show up. Objective Deliver a tread compound that passes dry handling and snow traction while keeping extrusion processability clean, so you can scale a balanced all-season. How can we assist your R&D We don‚Äôt guess formulas. We based our research on public technical knowledge (patents, journals, sheets) and when allowed, your data to predict what will work on your tools. The levers that move the needle Keep it private and traceable Your raw data stays on your side; only the model learnings move. This means lineage end-to-end; you can track each run, from batch to mixing, through tests to the final result. That makes success repeatable and off-spec issues quick to fix. How it looks with our AI platform Dry vs. Snow map: pick dry-ranked routes (A‚ÄìB), snow-ranked routes (green), or all-rounders (C), then use the inorganic package as the tuning screw to move into your target corner-without breaking processability What does this mean? Results in manufacturing The question isn‚Äôt ‚Äúwhich filler wins?‚Äù but ‚Äúwhich package wins for this market and tire class?‚Äù Product choices When we train on your on-site data, predictive reliability typically improves by 20%+ over the public-only baseline (directional; depends on data depth) Business Value Final Results Area Before with typical process After with CrowdChem's AI Objectives & gates Shifting criteria Defined dry/snow indices + extrusion = PASS Formulation search Broad trial and error Shortlist (3-4 routes) with rationale (inorganic packprocess by target) What's delivered Point results per run Operating window (families + ranges) + process guardrails Manufacturability Edge cutting/burning at low oil Clean extrusion under low-oil rules with Ti-BR Iterations Many runs; months Fewer runs, weeks to reach PASS Iterations/Time Many runs; months to reach \ 95% fewer runs, only weeks to achieve \ With our AI platform we can automatically standardize variables, rangers, and test methods (rubber architecture, filler budget, oil limits, extrusion check; dry/snow/chipping screens). Broaden and normalize. If necessary we map out related sources and your results to the same yardsticks, then model which levers move dry, snow, chipping and processability for your target lines. Outlined window. Outputs are an explainable shortlist and an operating window you can run. Inorganic package (surface & contact ‚Äúorder‚Äù): treated talc, alumina-treated rutile TiO‚ÇÇ, and fine spherical silica sharpen dry handling when adjusted in low single-digit, without spiking chipping. Inorganic for snow (micro-mechanical anchoring): expanded graphite, fused spherical alumina, and silane-treated talc systematically lift snow indicated at low single-digit while respecting oil/filler balance. Backbone & oil rules (manufacturability): the Ti-catalyzed Butadiene Rubber + Natural Rubber frame keeps extrusion quality low oil; switching Butadiene Rubber catalysts breaks processability even if other knobs ‚Äúlook right‚Äù. Why this matters: you sell confidence in braking and steering, with durability and a compound the plant can actually run. Business translation; fewer defects, less rework, less waste and less runs An automated importance map (one-page): which levers (rubber raws, oil, silica, inorganics) move dry, snow, chipping, and processability. The redder the more impact it has. Explainable shortlist (3-4 routes): for your market/segment (dry-biased UHP, snow-lean all-season, or balanced touring), with confidence and the ‚Äúwhy‚Äù. Operating window + guardrails: practical ranges for the filler split + specialty inorganic white holding oil ‚â§15% of filler and the Natural Rubber/Ti-Butadiene Rubber (BR) balance, so do see clean edges and tests see the balance. Snow: farther right = better traction/handling in snow Dry: higher = better grip/steering on dry pavement Upper right = rare ‚Äúboth win‚Äù Points here deliver strong dry and strong snow A-B dry-rank leaders: excellent dry response with acceptable snow performance C: solid all-rounder trending toward the ‚Äúboth win‚Äù corner Warm markets: start from A-B routes. Validate chipping/resistance and keep extrusion clean. All-season/northern markets: start from the snow cluster. Confirm steering feel on clean pavement. Balanced touring: C-type routes are the best first bet; small tweaks can nudge them toward your target corner Fewer blind iterations: start inside a target window; use the inorganic package as a tuning screw by climate and segment Manufacturing confidence: the low-oil + Ti BR frame protects extrusion quality as you tune performance Line clarity: ‚Äúfor northern winter, package A; for dry performance, package B‚Äù same backbone, faster launches

title: Oil-based color cosmetics that apply smooth, stay stable, and don‚Äôt bleed
caption: CASE Oil-based color cosmetics that apply smooth, stay stable, and don‚Äôt bleed Overview Oil-based color isn‚Äôt only about richer shine, it solves three things at once: silky application, clean set, and practical stability. Oils wet pigments well, so color goes on smooth and even with high payoff. With the right film-forming system, the film sets without bleeding even in humidity. And because the base is anhydrous and properly structured, it stays stable on the shelf (no gritty clumps) and re-disperses with a quick shake. The Challenge Lowering viscosity makes metal-oxide pigments agglomerate and settle. Pushing pigment load for payoff can hurt re-dispersibility and stability. Thickening to stop bleeding risks a heavy, sticky feel. In sum, flow, load, stability, and non-bleed pull in different directions Objective Deliver an oil-based makeup that glides at low viscosity, carries high pigment for rich payoff, stays stable at temperature, and doesn‚Äôt bleed after set, all while remaining reproducible on your lines Why is it important? In the market it can be seen as follow; How we get you to your desired result With our AI platform we combine public technical knowledge (patents, papers, datasheets) and when allowed with your lab/plant results, to predict what works on your tools When it comes to oil-based cosmetics we need to understand which levers are the most relevant for viscosity, pigment dispersion, re-dispersability, high-temp stability and bleed The levers that move the needle Keep it private and traceable Your raw data stays on your side; only the model learnings move. This means lineage end-to-end; you can track each run, from batch to mixing, through tests to the final result. That makes success repeatable and off-spec issues quick to fix. What are we looking for Target-style windows: How it looks with our AI platform Shortlist routes that land in the top-left window deliver no-bleed at humidity and easy shake-back, by tuning pigment treatment, film former, and structuring together. What does this mean? Target-style window results The current use case was trained with public data, if combined data is used, predictive reliability typically improves by 20%+ over the public-only baseline (directional; depends on data depth) An oil-based cosmetic business results Final Results Area Before with typical process After with CrowdChem's AI Objectives & gates Unclear targets Defined: no bleed at humidity, easy re-dispersion and silky glide Formulation search Broad trial and error Shortlist (3-4 routes) with rationale: hydrophobized pigment treatment, film former, structuring system What's delivered Point results per batch Operating window (families + ranges) with process guardrails Iterations/Time Edge cutting/burning at low oil 90% fewer run, weeks to reach PASS Add-on knowledge Many runs; slow convergence All the insight from the industry know-how, none of data risk Liquid eyeliners (8%+ annually): long-lasting, non-bleeding lines with clean application. Waterproof cosmetics (10%+ annually): high-temp stability without heavy film Premium cosmetics (12%+ annually): high pigment payoff with smooth spread. Oil-based makeup (7%+ annually): excellent re-dispersibility and shelf stability We automatically frame variables, ranges, process steps, and test methods We then train it with both data merged and predict an operating window for the most promising component families and process guardrails. Pigment surface treatment sets edge definition and re-dispersion. Treated, well-wetted pigments give clean, no-bleed lines and few shakes to re-mix after standing. Film-former chemistry locks the set The right backbone/co-film former combo delivers humidity-stable edges (no feathering) while keeping the swipe silky, not stiff. Structuring system (soft network strength) governs shake-back and feel. A balance network prevents hard settling yet yields with 2-3 shakes, avoiding grit or pasty pickup. Volatile/non-volatile balance tunes glide vs. final hold enough slip for smooth application, enough cohesion to stay put. Why does it matter?: A stick/liquid that applies smoothly, sets cleanly without bleeding, and re-disperses quickly means fewer customer complaints, less rework and waste, and a product that wins on shelf and in daily use. A film-forming silicone backbone that dries clean and helps prevent bleed Dextrin fatty-acid ester + organo-modified clay working synergistically to reduce agglomeration and improve re-dispersion Hydrophobized metal-oxide pigments at high yet manageable load for intense color. A volatile oil phase that supports quick dry-down and pleasant feel. Viscosity ‚Üí smooth application without slump Hydrophobized pigment content ‚Üí high payoff without collapse. Quality checks: no severe agglomeration, re-dispersion after standing, high-temp stability, long-wear / non-bleed. An automated one-page importance map: Our platform creates a clear heatmap showing which knobs most effect viscosity, dispersion, re-dispersion, high-temp stability and non-bleed. It speeds alignment across R&D, marketing and operations. The redder the lever, the more it moves the targets. An Explainable shortlist (3-5 routes): Each one includes the reasoning and a confidence band. Where to act so your lab can confirm quickly. Clear choices, no black box. Operating window + guardrails: Practical ranges for flow and film formation so results repeat across batches and lines. Re-dispersability number of shakes needed for re-mix: farther left = fewer shakes (better) ‚Üí gives a clean and uniform swipe (no grits/streaks). High-humidity stability, the closer to 1.0 the better: higher = cleaner edges after set (less bleed/feathering in humid conditions). Formulas inside the viscosity window applied cleanly and reduced bleed. Hydrophobized pigments avoided severe agglomeration and re-dispersed after standing. The dextrin-ester + organoclay pair behaved as a high-impact lever for high-temp stability and re-dispersion. A volatile-oil + film-former backbone improved dry-down without pushing viscosity out of range. Better user experience: silky glide, rich color payoff, no grit, no migration. Fewer reformulations and returns: stronger stability and re-dispersion reduce rework and delays. Scale with confidence: once the window is set, it replicates; lineage keeps it there. We learn on-site, your raw data never leaves. Only model updates are shared.

title: The Challenge of Sustainable Food Packaging: Finding the Perfect Balance
caption: CASE The Challenge of Sustainable Food Packaging: Finding the Perfect Balance Overview In the quest for sustainable solutions, polylactic acid (PLA) bio-resins have emerged as a promising material for foam sheets used in food containers. But while the PLA market is growing, the challenge remains: Surface vs. insulation: larger cells / lower density help insulation but roughen the skin and hurt sealing/fit; very fine cells improve appearance but can collapse during forming if the melt isn't tuned Heat resistance vs. toughness: raising heat resistance can make PLA brittle unless crystallization and particle interfaces are controlled. The fundamental problem isn't a lack of a biodegradable material, but a flaw in traditional R&D methods that can't balance critical properties. This results in an inevitable trade-off between a smooth surface and thermal insulation Why it matters The reality is, sustainability is no longer a \ Objective Create a lower-impact PLA foam sheet that stays light and form-stable while delivering a smooth, sealable surface suitable for food packaging. How it‚Äôs shown in the market How can we help you to tackle the challenge We use our AI platform trained on public technical data, and when allowed with your runs too. It automatically standardizes what to measure and how (variables, ranges, process and test methods), and predicts an operating window for the most promising component families and process guardrails. In PLA foams, our model consistently surfaced the critical control parameters that map directly to foam quality, so you get a silky surface and reliable heat-hold through tuned melt strength, controlled nucleation, and stable interfaces. The levers that move the needle Keep it private and traceable Your raw data stays on your side; only the model learnings move. This means lineage end-to-end; you can track each run, from batch to mixing, through tests to the final result. That makes success repeatable and off-spec issues quick to fix. How it is presented to you Shortlist routes A‚ÄìC land inside the operating window (red) where fine bubbles + mid-light density deliver smooth, sealable surfaces and clean forming route D sits outside and degrades appearance/seal. What does this mean? The operating window is where our targets converge; clean thermoforming and a smooth, sealable surface. Achieved with mid-light density and small, even cells. When we train on your on-site data, predictive reliability typically improves by 20%+ over the public-only baseline (directional; depends on data depth) Business Value Final Results Area Before with typical process After with CrowdChem's AI Objectives & gates Incomplete or shifting criteria Defined surface/seal = PASS Thermoforming = PASS Formulation search Broad trial and error, with unclear levers Shortlist 3-5 routes with clear levers and impact on formulation What's delivered Point per result Operating window, an active learning algorithm and process guardrails Validation Long cycles and tests Compact plan using proven data Line repeatability Variable across shifts/tools Proven test methods + guardrails to hold the window Iterations/Time Many runs; months to reach ‚ÄúPASS‚Äù 95% fewer runs, only weeks to achieve ‚ÄúPASS‚Äù Food packaging: (8% + annually) Biodegradable alternative to polystyrene foam Eco-friendly Materials: (15% + annually) Meets environmental regulations Takeout containers: (12% + annually) Heat resistant, microwave-safe Fresh Food Trays: (10% + annually) Superior insulation properties Mineral particle choice & treatment (plus a sensible amount) set the bubble size and surface smoothness.. Heating stages and gas/foaming conditions mainly tuned overall weight/insulation and keep the sheet stable through die and forming. Why those matter: a lighter sheet that thermoform predictably, with smooth, sealable surface and fewer defects, means less rework, less waste, and lower environmental impact. An automated one-page importance map. We show the levers that matter most for your goals, what to adjust, where it sits in the formula, and how it affects surface smoothness, lamination/seal, and insulation. It‚Äôs a simple visual: the redder the lever, the more it moves your targets An explainable shortlist (3‚Äì5 routes) from a sea of options, to a small set of component families with confidence and brief ‚Äúwhy this works‚Äù.Clear choices, no black box. An operating window ready for run tests (how cell size, density, and formability line up) and a compact validation plan your team already knows: check apparent density, confirm cell size, and run basic compression/thermoform screens. Fast to prove, easy to scale. Density: lighter to the left, heavier to the right. Lighter helps insulation/weight; too light risks collapse in forming. Bubble diameter: Dry: higher = better grip/steering on dry pavement Fewer reformulations, faster launches: start inside the right window; bypass the ‚Äúrough surface vs. collapse‚Äù loop that stalls pilots. Differentiated performance: smooth, sealable surfaces with useful insulation at line speed, an immediate advantage in food trays and take-out lids. Defensible position: We turn trial-and-error into a run-ready operating window, the ranges and how to hold them, creating a real edge in time-to-market.
